Description: Body sherd of pottery open vessel, probably a bowl; grey-whitish slip; interior glazed black; exterior, from top: tongue or guilloche band; 'z' frieze; pendent rays.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The general appearance suggests Lakonian production, though the collocation of decorative elements is not readily parallelled.
Lemos identifies the sherd as belonging to a Chian Chalice Style vase but the fabric is not Chian and the decoration is not consistent with other Chian decorated wares.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 2, pl. 3, no. 9)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 307, no. 1255, pl. 161)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GC.77)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
